title.narrative: PUBLIC OVERSIGHT FOR BETTER GOVERNANCE

description.narrative: Public oversight bodies related to children, including the Parliament, Ombudsman's Office, Anti-Discrimination Commissioner, civil society organizations and the media, increasingly demand accountability of duty-bearers for better governance results for children., which contributes to Adolescent Empowerment, Child Poverty / Public Finance For Children, Child Protection â€“ General, Children In Urban Settings / Local Governance, Corporate External Relations And Partnerships, Communication And Resource Mobilization, Education â€“ General, Health Systems Strengthening, Human Rights Institutions, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Policy Advocacy â€“ Urban, Civil Society, Parliament, Environment, Public Finance And Local Governance, Social Protection And Child Poverty. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: OUTCOME 1 - GOVERNANCE FOR CHILDREN Effective public oversight and monitoring of institutions help to ensure implementation of policies and programmes addressing the needs and rights of marginalized children.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Public oversight bodies related to children, including the Parliament, Ombudsman's Office, Anti-Discrimination Commissioner, civilsociety organizations and the media, increasingly demand accountability of duty-bearers for better governance results for children.

description.narrative: UNICEF assisted Albania&39;s Parliament and national human rights institutions to strengthen their oversight of duty-bearers&39; accountability for child rights upholding (with focus, in 2016, on the situation of children in detention, in residential care and on the move); civil society partners were supported in strategic litigation cases for child rights. | Status:Met | As-of Date:08/01/2017

title.narrative: % of Albania's regions (Qarqu) having established and functional Child Rights Units

baseline.value: No institutional system for child rights monitoring prior to the adoption of the Law 10347 On the Protection of the Rights of the Child (came into force in June 2011)

target.value: 2014:100%, 12 Child Rights Units (CRUs) to be established and functional in all 12 Regional Councils as part of Albania

actual.value: 2017:CRUs layer replaced by the SACRP direct collaboration with the reformed Municipalities and direct technical supervision of municipal Child Protection Workers

title.narrative: of mechanisms and structures holding on-going dialogue between interest/user groups /networks/ alliances / CSOs at local and national level

baseline.value: No mechanism for child rights monitoring by civil society prior to the adoption of the Law 10347 On the Protection of the Rights of the Child (came into force in 2011)

target.value: 2014:Child Rights Observatories (CROs) are established and their operational and financial sustainability mechanisms developed in all 12 regions of Albania

actual.value: 2017:Child Rights Observatories are functional at all 12 regions of Albania

title.narrative: of parliamentary hearings /standing committee discussions annually on child-related issues

actual.value: 2017:At least 7 discussions on issues related to children:1.Plenary session reviews of the Annual Report of the People's Advocate and of the Commissioner for Protection from Discrimination, including for child rights cases.2.One public hearing session of the Parliamentary Sub-commission on Children,

title.narrative: % of major child-related complaints effectively addressed by the Ombudsman Office (of the total number submitted to Ombudsman) annually

actual.value: 2017:For 2015: Of 136 cases of child-related concerns reviewed by the People's Advocate 56 (43%) were either resolved positively to the benefit of the children concerned, or followed up with recommendations by the People's Advocate, in favour of the child.
